fields.headline: In brief
fields.bodyText: Ebbers set to take the stand Bernard Ebbers, the former WorldCom chief executive, is expected to take the witness stand in New York today to defend himself against fraud and conspiracy charges. His attorney, Brian Heberlig, disclosed plans to put Mr Ebbers on the stand during a hearing with prosecutors and the judge in the case, which relates to an $11bn (£5.7bn) accounting scandal at the telecommunications company. Mr Ebbers, 63, is charged with fraud, conspiracy and filing false documents with regulators. He faces up to 85 years in prison if convicted on all counts. The prosecution alleges that Mr Ebbers masterminded the fraud so that WorldCom could meet Wall Street's profit estimates and slow the decline in its stock price. Barracuda may be put on sale Barracuda, the pubs and bars group, could be put up for sale. Analysts believe the group could be valued about £300m. The owner of the Buckinghamshire-based Barracuda, which owns the Varsity, Smith & Jones and Barracuda bar chains, confirmed it had appointed the investment bank Citigroup to look at several options, including a sale to a private equity firm, a stock market flotation or a refinancing. £19m payout for Asda workers More than 113,000 staff at the Asda supermarket chain have received a share of annual bonuses worth a record £19m. Workers received an average of £264 in their pay packets on Friday as part of the benefits scheme, rising to £360 if their store outperformed its targets.
